Where did this happen?  I had a similar injury surfing.  Long ago, at Huntington Beach, I lost balance and fell backward.  My board flew forward. I drove slowly with my left hand holding my face and my right hand shifted gears and steered to the hospital where I had a number of stitches. Aloha Physics Girl, After viewing your video on Permafrost, I saw the video thumbnail with your shiner. It looked (do not ask me why) like you had gone surfing so I gave it a quick see and finished your shiner video. Your video was interesting but not entirely accurate. You did not consider the buoyancy issues of bubble infused seawater (suds) and its density differences from still water.

One physics issue with surfing waves over ten feet (or so, even overhead waves sometimes) is that suds are generated when the lip crashes into the base that change the density of the water in the impact zone. Too many drownings occur each year because gremmies try to swim through the suds above them. To surf big waves, you have to train to hold your breath for about 2 minutes for ten foot waves and about 3 minutes, or more, for 15-20 foot waves.

The reason for this long period is because you have to wait for the suds' bubbles to rise to the surface so the water becomes dense enough to swim to the surface. With the bubbles, your body stays at the depth of equilibrium and trying to swim up is like flapping your arms to fly on dry land. Then once you reach the surface, you have about enough time to take one breath before you get caught in the next wave and the suds generated by that water on water impact.

In that 5-15 second period, you have to orient to the various safe zones available to you depending on the break. Then you have to do it all over again. Soon (it has to be or you drown), you realize that you can swim under the suds to the various safe zones; and then you train for how to swim fast underwater. So much fun!

Now I realize that I am describing the extreme conditions of advanced surfing, but it is only to give you an easy to empathize scenario for the physics of the washing machine as we call the crashing waves you enjoyed. It also may help you realize the skill required for water men and women who live to tell about it. They may not have the physics knowledge you regularly present in your videos, but they understand enough to survive in very adversarial conditions. Aloha

Surfing Trauma Story Time!
The very first time I learned how to surf, I was told I was "A natural" ... whatever that means.
Apparently my stance was good and my ability to stay on the board was "uncanny."
So of course, you tell me this, and I'm like "I AM THE PROPHECIZED KING OF SURFING! WATCH ME IN AWE!"
And that equated to me trying to emulate what I'd always seen in pop media depicting surfing, I decided to "Hang Ten."
PHYSICS STORY TIME!
Turns out, if you stand on one end of a surfboard, thereby applying a downward force to it, there is an equal and opposite force at the other end of the board pushing up.
Sooo.. The board IMMEDIATELY flipped headlong and THUNKED me on the back of the head so hard it forced me under the water and I literally ate sand. (Also had some shoved up my nose.)
So there I am, concussed, underwater, completely confused and disoriented, trying to repeat the mantra I heard from Adam Savage once "Calm people live, Scared people die" over and over as I figure out what I should do, all while tumbling across the sandy shore bottom.
I immediately cover my head and calmly ball up, when the wave stops tumbling I stick a leg out and find the bottom and kick off up and break the surface spittin' and chokin' on sand and brine.
And then the worst part happened.
I realized literally EVERYONE had just watched me totally BEEF it and the shame settled in. :')
And I never surfed again.
The end!

I’m 71 and while that is no great achievement in itself, I owe my relative longevity to something I practice: risk assessment. Observing people engaged in activities from the mundane to outright lethal, I make note of the outcomes. It wasn’t until 1978 when someone I knew jumped from a height of over 300 feet and the airbag failed to break the fall that I started to think about measuring risk and reward. A helicopter crash, motorcycle crash, three tingly near misses of lightning reminds you that you can’t think of every variable. Almost getting pitched out of a VLA Radio Telescope dish is more of reminder that if there is a checklist, do not skip anything.

A good friend suffered from a fairly severe concussion while we were snowboarding. He took a jump and basically landed on his head... knocked himself out for about 5 minutes and wound up in the hospital that evening. After all the typical symptoms in the first few hours (loss of short-term memory, slurred speach, etc), and a few days of recovery, he settled into a weird state that took a whole year to heal.

The weird state was that cognitively he was operating at 80%, but he had somehow lost the filter that normally resides between the random thoughts we all have in our brains, and his mouth. So literally anything could pop out. That plus a bit of fuzz didn't resolve for an entire year. As we are both programmers and operate at very high cognitive levels, the loss of function was very obvious. A whole year like that.

-Matt

1:53 I definitely know that feeling after getting hurt... know it much better than I wished.
And most of the time the injury turns out to be one of the worst things I imagined.
At least I'm getting good at estimating the recovery times from broken bones 🙈

Also I noticed that from almost every injury I remember the (fraction of) a second leading up to it, reliving that painful anticipation when I know I'm about to get hurt, dozens of times before recovering and even years later from time to time. That's probably one of the worst but simultaneously most useful part because that knowledge is essential to avoid the same mistake in the future.

But I definitely recommend anyone: be careful! You only have one life, and you are not the only one to whom that life matters. So stay safe and before taking risks, think about whether the potential reward is worth it.

It's nice to know I'm also keeping other water users safe by being in control of my equipment at all times.

(The doctors checked my eyesight and helped me craft my story about the 50 ft wave, with the shark and the child I saved, but they didn't mention a concussion). The day after I filmed this, I felt really down and depressed. Then 2 days letter, felt happy again, like mood whiplash. I found out a week later I had a concussion and would have definitely not filmed the JWST video the same day, had I known. A dire warning for the lot of you!
